{"id":3,"topic":"Collect x,x^2,x^3","question":"Simplify {a}x+{b}x^2+{c}x+{d}x^2+{e}x^3","working":"{a}x+{b}x^2+{c}x+{d}x^2+{e}x^3
=({a}+{c})x+({b}+{d})x^2+{e}x^3
={a+c}x+{b+d}x^2+{e}x^3","answer":"{a+c}x+{b+d}x^2+{e}x^3","help":"x,x^2 and x^3 are not the same. We can only collect like powers.","variables":"a=[2..9]
b=[2..9]
c=[2..8]
d=[2..9]
e=[3..8]
{≠a,b,c,d,e}","topics":"algebra2"}

{"id":4,"topic":"expand {a}({b}x+{c})","question":"Expand {a}({b}x+{c})","working":"{a}({b}x+{c})
={a}*{b}x+{a}*{c}
={a*b}x+{a*c}","answer":"{a*b}x+{a*c}","help":"To expand brackets multiply every term in the bracket by the number outside.
4(2x+3)=4*2x+4*3=8x+3
Note: 4(2x+3) means 4\(\times(\)(2x+3)\()\)
We could do the same for numbers:
4(3+2)=4*3+4*2=12+8=20
but since we can calculate the bracket first it usually makes more sense to do this:
4(3+2)=4*5=20","variables":"a=[2..9]
b=[2..9]
c=[2..8]
{≠a,b,c}","topics":"algebra2"}

{"id":5,"topic":"Expand ({a}x+{b})({c}x+{d})","question":"Expand ({a}x+{b})({c}x+{d})","working":"({a}x+{b})({c}x+{d})
={a}x({c}x+{d})+{b}({c}x+{d})
={a}x*{c}x+{a}x*{d}+{b}*{c}x+{b}*{d}
={a*c}x^2+{a*d}x+{b*c}x+{b*d}
={a*c}x^2+{a*d+b*c}x+{b*d}","answer":"{a*c}x^2+{a*d+b*c}x+{b*d}","help":"To expand brackets multiply every term in the first bracket by every term in the second bracket.
(4x+2)(2x+3)
=4x(2x+3)+2(2x+3)
=4x*2x+4x*3+2*2x+2*3
=8x^2+12x+4x+6
=8x^2+16x+6
Note: 4x*2x
=4\(\times\)x*2\(\times\)x
=4*2\(\times\)x\(\times\)x
=8x^2
FOIL (first outer inner last) can be used to remember how to expand 2x2 brackets but better to understand the process which is far more general:
(3x+2y+7)(2x+z+3)
=6x^2+3xz+9x+4xy+2yz+6y+14x+7z+21

{"id":11,"topic":"Solve {a}x+{b}={c}x+{d}","question":"Solve
{a}x+{b}={c}x+{d}","working":"{a}x+{b}={c}x+{d}
{b}-{d}={c}x-{a}x
{b-d}={c-a}x
x={b-d}/{c-a}?={(b-d)/(c-a)}
alternatively
{a}x+{b}={c}x+{d}
{a}x-{c}x={d}-{b}
{a-c}x={d-b}
x={d-b}/{a-c}?={(d-b)/(a-c)}","answer":"[x=]{(d-b)/(a-c)}#","help":"See @algebra
It is generally easiest (but not required) to collect terms such that x remains positive. 
3x+7=5x-2
7+2=5x-3x
9=2x
x=9/2
... but the alternative is fine too
3x+7=5x-2
3x-5x=-2-7
-2x=-9
x=(-9)/-2=9/2","variables":"a=[1..8]
b=[2..9]

{"id":48,"topic":"fractional powers","question":"Evaluate {a^b}^{1/b}","working":"{a^b}^{1/b}
=\(\sqrt[{b}]{a^b}\)={a}","answer":"{a}","help":"a^(1/n)=\(\sqrt[n]a\)

consider:
(a^(1/n))^n=a^(n/n)=a^1=a
(a^(1/n))^n=a so a^(1/n)=\(\sqrt[n]a\)

\(\sqrt[n]a\) means the  \(n\)th root of \(a\), i.e. what number multiplied by itself n times gives \(a\).The root symbol alone means the square root, so \(\sqrt{}\) means the same as \(\sqrt[2]{}\)
8^(1/3)=\(\sqrt[3]8\)=2 since 2*2*2=8 

Note: the root symbol specifically means the positive root. For even powers we need to be careful solving equations of the form a^(2n)=x since both \(\sqrt[2n]x\) and \(-\sqrt[2n]x\) are solutions. This is typically show as \(\pm\sqrt[2n]x\).
x^2=4 \(\Longrightarrow x=\pm\sqrt{4}=\pm 2\) since 2*2=4 and -2*-2=4 (see @negatives)","variables":"xyz=a n x
a=[2..4]
b=[3..5]:{a^b<100}","topics":"powers4"}

help.title: Commutative
help.text:
An operator is known as commutative if switching the order of its operands gives the same result. 

Addition and multiplication are commutative:
4+5=5+4
6*7=7*6
Subtraction, division and powers are not commutative:
5-7\(\ne\)7-5
\(4\div9\ne9\div4\)
3^2\(\ne\)2^3

Treating division as fractions and "attaching" subtraction to make negatives can help make things more commutative.
-6+20=20-6
3/4*(5/6)=5/6*(3/4) =3*5/(4*6)=3/6*(5/4) (see @fractions)

help.title: Fractions
help.text: As your mathematics becomes stronger you will use fractions more and more, particularly in algebra. Make sure you understand how to add, subtract, multiply, divide and simplify. Equivalent fractions are formed by multiplying or dividing both numerator (top) and denominator (bottom) by the same amount. 6/8=3/4=9/12=600/800 You simplify a fraction by finding the smallest values (so 'numerator and 'denominator have no common factors). 600/800=3/4 You may also convert improper (top heavy) fractions into 'mixed numbers by dividing the 'denominator into the 'numerator and finding the remainder. 23/3= 7+2/3 To add or subtract fractions you must first have a common denominator. We can only add or subtract things when they are the same type of thing. 3/4+5/6=9/12+10/12=19/12= 1+7/12 2/5-1/4=8/20-5/20=3/20 Multiplication does not need a common denominator. Just multiply the 'numerators and multiply the denominators. 2/3*(3/4)=2*3/(3*4)=6/12=1/2 Better still cancel down early to keep numbers small and avoid the need to simplify. 2/3*(3/4)=\(\'dfrac{\color{pink}\'cancel2\color{black}1}{\color{lightblue}\'cancel3 \color{black}1}\times\'dfrac{\color{lightblue}\'cancel3 \color{black}1}{\color{pink}\'cancel4 \color{black}2}\)= 1/2 of means the same as multiplying. 2/3 of 3/4=2/3*(3/4)=1/2 Division is the opposite of multiplication. Dividing by \(\frac{1}{2}\) is the same as multiplying by 2. To divide fractions flip the fraction you are dividing by and multiply. 2/3÷(3/4)=2/3*(4/3)=8/9 You may also think of this process in terms of simplification. 2/3÷(3/4)= (2/3)/(3/4)=(2/3*4*3)/(3/4*4*3)=8/9 Multiplying through by denominators can be a useful technique for removing double-decker fractions when they arise in more complex algebra. We tend not to use the division symbol in more advanced mathematics.

help.title: Keyboard
help.text:
Click <button class='btn btn-xs kbd'>​</button> to enter your answer. Use <button class='btn btn-xs btn-success'>✓</button> to mark.

A question mark will be shown where your answer can't be understood (sometimes followed by an indication of what is wrong).

The display follows the rules of @precedence. Use ^ for powers, / for division and * for multiplication.  Check that what is displayed is mathematically equivalent to what you mean and add or remove brackets as needed.
E.g. enter '3x^5/(7y^3) for 3x^5/(7y^3)

Functions (sin,cos,tan,ln etc.) are treated as having precedence between addition and multiplication, add brackets if that's not what you want. Trigonometric powers and inverse functions can be entered with ^ (e.g. sin^2 for \(\sin^2\) and sin^-1 for \(\sin^{-1}\)).

Brackets will automatically be shown where needed to avoid ambiguity and removed where they are not needed. Pay attention to what is shown to develop your understanding of @precendece (a key skill for algebraic re-arrangement).

help.title: Negatives
help.text:
Make sure you understand the rules:
\(++=+\)
\(+-=-\)
\(-+=-\)
\(- -=+\)
The last one is where most mistakes are made, particularly when squaring numbers.
(-7)^2=-7*-7=49
Also remember that if you subtract a negative number you end up adding.
5\(-\)-6=5+6=11
Two negatives don't always make a positive.
-5-6=-11
-6\(-\)-5=-6+5=-1
Be careful. More errors are made with negatives than with any other part of mathematics.

help.title: Rating
help.text:
After each question rate your understanding to move on to the next question.
<g>:)</g> means you understand (little practice required).
<o>:|</o> means you are unsure (more practice required).
<r>:(</r> means you do not understand. More help needed.
You may also leave a comment to refer back to later.

A detailed colour-coded record is kept of everything you do. 
Question are shown as <g>green</g> when you get them correct and rate <g>:)</g>, <r>red</r> when you get them wrong or rate <r>:(</r> or <o>amber</o> otherwise. 
Papers are marked <g>green</g> when all questions are green, <r>red</r> when any questions are red, or <o>amber</o> otherwise.

You can click on any of the paper or question links to find more detail and try again.
You may also use "Tutor" to allow parents, teachers or tutors to see your results.

Over time try to turn everything on your "Home" page <g>green</g>.

help.title: Precedence
help.text:
The more powerful the operator the sooner it is evaluated. You may know as BIDMAS, BODMAS or BEDMAS.
  • Brackets are evaluated first.
  • Powers are evaluated next (B?DMAS).
  • Division or Multiplication are evaluated next.
  • Addition or Subtraction are evaluated last.
Note: Division has the same precedence as multiplication. Addition has the same precedence as subtraction. Most calculators and computers follow the rules automatically. These rules are really important. Without precendence algebraic re-arrangement would be order-dependent, so very complex.

help.title: Distributive
help.text: An operator is known as distributive if we can expand brackets. Multiplication distributes over addition and is the most common use of the distributive property. 4(5+3)=4*5+4*3=20+12=32 Normally we would simply calculate the bracket first. So 4(5+3)=4*8=32 but if dealing with algebra we can only expand using the distributive property since we don't know values of x,y etc. 4(2x+5y)=8x+20y Powers are distributive over multiplication but not over addition. (3*5)^2=3*5*3*5=3^2*5^2 (see @commutative) (3+5)^2\(\ne\)3^2+5^2 Division is right but not left distributive over addition. (3+5)÷4=3÷4+5÷4 4÷(3+5)\(\ne\)4÷3+4÷5 it is however best to avoid division and express as fractions instead (see @fractions). (3+5)/4 or 4/(3+5)

help.title: Factors
help.text: Factorisation is a key skill in mathematics. One number is a factor of another if it divides into it with no remainder. 3 is a factor of 6, 4 is a factor of 20. Factors always come in pairs. 20=1*20 20=2*10 20=4*5 So 20 has factors 1,2,4,5,10 & 20 The same is true in algebra except we are also dealing with symbols in addition to numbers. x and 3 are factors of 3x. x,y,xy,x^2 and x^2y are all factors of x^3y. Prime Factorisation A particularly powerful technique when looking for factors is prime factorisation. Primes are numbers which have exactly two factors (one and themselves), so no other numbers divide into them exactly. Every number can be decomposed into the product of its prime factors. It can be helpful to think of this as the fingerprint or DNA of a number, since it is unique to every different number. We tend to use power notation to shorten the expression and arrange prime factors in size order. 8=2*2*2=2^3 45=3*3*5=3^2*5 Note: 1 is not defined as a prime since it has only one factor (itself). To find prime factors either systematically check for division by increasing primes (2,3,5,7,11...), or decompose into larger factor you can immediately spot and then break these down. 132=2*66=2*2*33=2*2*3*11=2^2*3*11 or 132=11*12=11*4*3=11*2*2*3=2^2*3*11 Once you have prime factors it is relatively easy to find all other factors by considering the different combinations. 132=\(2×(2×3×11)\)=2*66 132=\(3×(2×2×11)\)=3*44 132=\((2×2)×(3×11)\)=4*33 132=\((2×3)×(2×11)\)=6*22 132=\(11×(2×2×3)\)=11*12 Spotting factors is particularly important for solving @quadratics and simplifying @fractions Highest Common Factor When simplifying or factorising we often want to find the largest factor which divides into two different terms. 4 is the HCF of 12 and 40 3x is the HCF of 9x^2 and 12x Lowest Common Multiple Sometimes we need to find the smallest number which has two different factors, 36 is the LCM of 12 and 9 It is less common to want to find the LCM of algebraic terms however but

help.title: Algebra
help.text: Algebra replaces numbers with letters to "generalise" what the mathematics means. The rules are identical for numbers and algebra. 1+2 is a single sum, which has only one answer. x+y is every possible sum! This is amazingly powerful and gives mathematics much of its beauty. Algebra is commonly know as the language of mathematics. The main skills required for manipulating algebra are described below. Note: we try to avoid using the \(\times\) symbol with algebra. Lack of a symbol means \(\times\), so 3x means 3\(\times\)x. Substitution Substitution turns general into specific. Find x^2+5y where x=4 and y=-3 x^2+5y=4^2+5*-3=16-15=1 Collecting like terms We simplify by adding up all the terms which are the same. x+2y+3x-5y-7z+5x^2+4z-3x^2+4y =(5-3)x^2+(1+3)x+(2-5+4)y+(4-7)z =2x^2+4x+y-3z Note: 1y=y, x and x^2 are related but different terms so are collected individually. Expanding Since we don't know the values x,y etc. we can't work out the value of what is in a bracket, we can however expand brackets (see @distributive). 3(2x-5y)=3*2x+3*-5y=6x-15y When expanding multiple brackets we take each in turn and then collect like terms. (3x-2y)(x+4y)=3x(x+4y)-2y(x+4y) =3x^2+12xy-2xy-8y^2 =3x^2+10xy-8y^2 Note: xy=yx (see @commutative) You may have been taught to expand 2x2 brackets using FOIL (first outer inner last). Expanding brackets is a far more general skill than just 2x2 brackets. Factorising Factorising is the opposite of expanding. We factorise by breaking out the highest common factor of an expression. 9x^2+24x=3x(3x+8) This is an important skill. See @factors and @quadratics for more detail. Solving Solving equations is perhaps the most powerful application of algebra. The golden rule is that an equation will remain true provided you do exactly the same thing to both sides. 1=1 1+5=1+5 (1+5)*2=(1+5)*2 We use this fact to solve equations: 3x+7=5x-2 7=2x-2 (subtract 3x from each side) 9=2x (add 2 to each side) x=9/2=4.5 (divide both sides by 2) As you get more proficient with algebra you will find this becomes very natural and more visual. Additive items change sign as they go across the equals and multiplicative items go up-and-down stairs. Do however always be careful with @negatives and @precedence as this is where most errors are made. (3x+2)÷3=x+2/3 not x+2 Note: the only thing you are not allowed to do is divide by zero. Some care is also needed when taking roots to avoid losing negative solutions. Changing the subject Changing the subject of a formula is a useful skill (particularly for Physics) employing exactly the same skills as solving equations. y=3x+7 \(\Rightarrow\) x=(y-7)/3 (see solving above) These formulae are mathematically identical but the first enables us to find y if we know x, and the 2nd lets us find x if we know y. For more complex re-arrangements take it one step at a time, isolating terms which involve the subject on one side of the equation and terms which don't on the other. You may need to expand and factorise to achieve this. 4(x+3)=y(1-x) 4x+12=y-xy 4x+xy=y-12 x(4+y)=y-12 x=(y-12)/(4+y)

help.title: instructions__home
help.text:
Use the Test button to check your knowledge and learn new skills.

When you have answered a question use the rating buttons to move on. Harder, similar or easier questions will be asked based on your rating (and whether you got the previous question correct).

If you get a question wrong always take the time to understand why. Use Show to see a fully worked solution. You can also contact us for help.

A <r>Corrections</r> button will appear for anything you need to correct. It is often best to wait a day or so before correcting (to make sure learning is remembered) but correct regularly. Aim to keep your pages as <g>green</g> as possible.

FreeMaths aims to make your practice as efficient and rewarding as possible.

help.text:
Information is broken into three sections: summary (students), tests and questions.

If you select a particular student, test or area all the figures will automatically update in all sections "drilling down" into the detail.

All sections are designed to float the most important items to the top, based on how many students flag difficulties and/or drop marks. Many items are hyper-linked and/or have hover-text providing more detail.

FreeMaths aims to make keeping track of student progress easy and efficient, whilst giving students the tools to work as independently as possible.

<o>Note:</o> the site is designed to work from a PC, tablet or phone, however to get the full power of the students page it is best used on a PC or Mac.  <g>Enjoy :)</g>

help.title: Quadratics
help.text: {xyz=a,b,c,x,y,z} Quadratics are equations of the form y=ax^2+bx+c e.g. y=2x^2+3x+5 When plotted, all quadratics give the same symmetrical shape. They are all transformations of the equation y=x^2. Depending on the values of a,b & c the graphs have slightly different properties. If a is positive the graph will be U shaped (happy) if a is negative the graph will be \(\cap\) shaped (unhappy). Solving Quadratics Typically we are interested in finding the roots of 'a quadratic, also known as solving. The roots of an equation are the values for which y = 0, so for 'a quadratic ax^2+bx+c=0 Any quadratic will have 0,1 or 2 real roots depending on the values of a,b & c. Specifically it will have: 0 real roots if b^2<4ac 1 (repeated) root if b^2=4ac 2 distinct roots if b^2>4ac For this reason b^2-4ac is known as the discriminant of 'a quadratic. In terms of their graphs, 'a quadratic with no roots stays below (\(\cap\)) or above (U) but does not cross the x axis, A quadratic with one root bounces off the x axis at the root. A quadratic with two roots crosses the x-axis at the two roots, with the middle of the curve exactly half way between them. There are three related algebraic techniques for solving quadratics, described below. Factorisation To factorise 'a quadratic we split it into two brackets. x^2+5x+6≡(x+3)(x+2) To do this we must find two factors of c which add to give b. So 2*3=6 and 2+3=5 in this case. Negatives make this slightly more complicated but the same rule applies. x^2-x-6=(x-3)(x+2) since 2*-3=-6 and -3+2=-1 a larger than 1 makes this considerably more complicated as we must then find factors of ac with add to give b 2x^2+7x+6 ac=2*6=12 3*4=12 3+4=7=b we then re-write and factorise 2x^2+4x+3x+6 =2x(x+2)+3(x+2) =(2x+3)(x+2) In effect this is the reverse of what you would do in expanding the brackets, but it is tricky and takes some practice. Once factorised solving is easy. (x+3)(x+2)=0⇒(x+3)=0 or (x+2)=0 'since if the product of two numbers is zero one or the other must 'be zero. thus x=-3 or x=-2 Note: the solutions are the opposite sign to the factorisation. A common error is to forget to change the sign. Completing the square Factorisation will only work where the roots are simple. Completing the square can 'be used on any quadratic (although the quadratic formula described below is generally faster when a≠1 or if b is not even). x^2+6x+4=0 re-write x^2+bx as (x+b/2)^2-(b/2)^2 (x+3)^2-9+4=0 (x+3)^2=5 x+3=±√5 x=-3±√5 so x=-3-√5 or x=-3+√5 Note: completing the square also automatically tells us the min(U) or max(\(\cap\)) value of the function 'since this will 'be when (x+b/2)^2=0, so will 'be at (-3,-5) in the above case. Quadratic Formula The quadratic formula comes directly from completing the square (see @quadratic_formula_proof) The solutions to ax^2+bx+c=0 are given 'by x=(-b±√(b^2-4ac))/(2a) Substitute the values for a,b, & c and the formula will give the solutions. 3x^2-7x+1=0 a=3, b=-7, c=1 x=(7±√(7^2-4*3*1))/(2*3) x=(7+√37)/6 or x=(7-√37)/6 Note: deal with negatives early. \(- -7\)=7 & (-7)^2=7^2. Be careful what you type into 'a calculator as -7^2≠(-7)^2. This formula also shows why we have no real solutions when b^2<4ac 'since we would need to take the square root of 'a negative number.

help.title: About
help.text:
Freemaths is designed to help students quickly develop their mathematics, whilst enabling parents and teachers to efficiently support this process.

An overview of how (and why) Freemaths works is given in this guide.

The easiest way to see what Freemaths does is to try it for yourself. Please contact us if you would like to know more or get involved. It is early days for the site but we look forward to helping every student perform well in mathematics.

As the name suggests use of the Freemaths site is completely free. The site carries no advertising and cookies are not used for any purpose other than identifying who you are for the site's functionality. The site is covered by UK data legislation with registration number Z8216806.

help.title: Classes FAQ
help.text:
Who are the classes suitable for?

The classes are ideal for students in year '10 or year '11 expecting to take GCSEs in '2018 or '2019.

What makes these Master classes?

The classes cover the most difficult GCSE topics. These topics are often covered very late by schools and not in great detail (or not at all for lower sets) but they are essential to gain the highest grades. Much of the joy in mathematics comes from the deeper understanding more advanced topics give.

Do students need to be high-performing to attend Master classes?

No, all that is required is a desire to do well and a willingness to invest the effort to do so. The classes aim to help all students to become high-performing.

Who will deliver the classes?

All classes will be delivered in person by Ed Darnell the creator of www.freemaths.uk

Ed is a highly qualified mathematics teacher with many years commercial computing and leadership experience. Ed holds a BSc. in Mathematics and Computing from Sheffield University and a PGCE and Masters in Mathematics Education from the Institute of Education.

What if I can’t make all classes?

The intention is to re-run the classes regularly so there is no need to attend them all at once. Why not try the first class and see how you get on?

Can I use www.freemaths.uk without attending classes?

Most definitely. The very best way to develop mathematics is by doing. The site has been specifically designed to help this, providing all the feedback students require to learn. It is completely free to use.

help.title: Typing Maths
powers
help.text:
{xyz=x,y,z,a,b,c}
x^a×x^b=x^(a+b)
x^0=1 (provided x≠0, 0^0 is undefined)
x^-a=1/x^a
x^(1/a)=\(\'sqrt[a]x\)
(x^a)^b=x^(ab)
(xy)^a=x^ay^a
Combining rules
(x/y)^-(a/b) =\(\'dfrac{(\'sqrt[b]y)^a}{(\'sqrt[b]x)^a}\)
Note: it does not matter which order you evaluate 'a power of -a/b but is generally better to do the root before the power as it keeps numbers smaller.

To understand power rules consider:
2^3*2^4=2^7
2*2*2 \(\;\'times\;\)2*2*2*2 =2*2*2*2*2*2*2
All other rules logically follow from the first.
x^a×x^-a=x^(a-a)=x^0=1
⇒ x^-a=1/x^a
x^(1/3)×x^(1/3)×x^(1/3)=\(x^{\'frac{1}{3}+\'frac{1}{3}+\'frac{1}{3}}\)=x^1=x
⇒ x^(1/3)=\(\'sqrt[3]x\)

help.title: surds
help.text:
{xyz=a,b,c}
√(ab)=√a√b
√(a/b)=√a/√b
Use these rules to simplify
E.g. √32=√16√2=4√2
To rationalise 'a simple denominator
x/√b=x/√b*(√b/√b)=x√(b)/b
E.g √2/√3=√2/√3*(√3/√3)=√6/3
To rationalise 'a more complex denominator
x/(√a+√b)=x/(√a+√b)*((√a-√b)/(√a-√b))=x(√a-√b)/(a-b)
Similarly
x/(√a-√b)=x/(√a-√b)*((√a+√b)/(√a+√b))=x(√a+√b)/(a-b)
E.g.
√2/(√3+√2)=√2/(√3+√2)*((√3-√2)/(√3-√2))=(√6-2)/1=√6-2
Note we are turning the denominator into 'a difference of squares which is why the surd vanishes.
(a+b)(a-b)≡a^2-b^2
